title: HubRouter: Learning Global Routing via Hub Generation and Pin-hub Connection
abstract: Global Routing (GR) is a core yet time-consuming task in VLSI systems. Recent machine learning approaches, especially generative models, suffer from non-connectivity in the generated routes, requiring extensive post-processing. To address this, the authors propose HubRouter, a novel two-phase learning scheme that redefines GR as a hub-pin connection problem. The first phase uses deep generative models in a multi-task framework to generate 'hubs'—key routing points—along with stripe masks to suppress noise. The second phase connects pins and hubs using an actor-critic model to construct a Rectilinear Steiner Minimum Tree (RSMT). Experiments show HubRouter outperforms state-of-the-art generative GR methods in wirelength, overflow, and runtime while guaranteeing connectivity. It also demonstrates generalizability to RSMT construction and interactive path replanning.
problem_description_natural: The paper addresses the global routing (GR) problem in VLSI physical design, which involves connecting multiple pins (terminals) of each net on a chip layout using routing paths through a grid of global routing cells (GCells). The goal is to minimize total wirelength while avoiding congestion (i.e., exceeding edge capacity limits), all while ensuring that all pins in a net are connected by a single continuous route. Traditional and recent learning-based methods either scale poorly or fail to guarantee connectivity in one-shot generative outputs, necessitating costly post-processing. HubRouter reframes this as a two-stage problem: first generating intermediate 'hub' points that capture essential topological features of valid routes, then efficiently connecting these hubs and pins into a fully connected tree structure.

lp_model.objective: $\min \left( \text{WL} + \lambda \text{OF} \right)$ where $\text{WL} = \sum_{e_{ij} \in \mathcal{E}} d_{ij} u_{ij}$ is total wirelength and $\text{OF} = \sum_{e_{ij} \in \mathcal{E}} \max(0, u_{ij} - c_{ij})$ is total overflow, with $\lambda$ as a weighting factor (though not explicitly specified, both are minimized in practice).
constraints: $\text{For each net } n \in N, \text{ the subgraph induced by edges with } x_{ij}^n = 1 \text{ must be connected and cover all pins in } P_n$.
variables: $x_{ij}^n$: binary decision variable indicating whether edge $e_{ij}$ is used for net $n$.
$u_{ij}$: total usage of edge $e_{ij}$, defined as the sum of $x_{ij}^n$ over all nets.

raw_latex_model: $$\begin{aligned} \min & \quad \sum_{e_{ij} \in \mathcal{E}} d_{ij} u_{ij} + \lambda \sum_{e_{ij} \in \mathcal{E}} \max(0, u_{ij} - c_{ij}) \\ \text{s.t.} & \quad \text{For each net } n \in N: \text{ the set } \{ e_{ij} : x_{ij}^n = 1 \} \text{ is connected and contains all pins in } P_n \\ & \quad u_{ij} = \sum_{n \in N} x_{ij}^n \quad \forall e_{ij} \in \mathcal{E} \\ & \quad x_{ij}^n \in \{0,1\} \quad \forall n \in N, e_{ij} \in \mathcal{E} \end{aligned}$$
algorithm_description: HubRouter is a two-phase learning scheme for global routing: 1) Hub-generation phase: Uses deep generative models (GAN, VAE, or DPM) in a multi-task framework to generate hubs (key points in routes) from condition images. 2) Pin-hub-connection phase: Employs an actor-critic model to construct rectilinear Steiner minimum trees (RSMT) by connecting generated hubs and pins, ensuring connectivity and minimizing wirelength and overflow.
